captions.text: Crowd: Good Morning Hank it's Tuesday!

John: So Hank, I've just finished Fox's tour
for The Fault in Our Stars movie

John [voice over]: featuring Shailene Woodley,
Ansel Elgort, and Nat Wolff, pictured here

dancing, getting psyched up for the show.
The tour started in Miami where everyone dramatically

underestimated how many people would show
up which led to big A/V problems and crowd

control and generally I'm just very sorry.
But lessons were learned and everyone was

much better prepared in Cleveland where several
thousand people wanted to say hello to you,
Hank.
Crowd: Good morning Hank [indistinct cheering]

John [voice over]: We were also reunited with
some of our friends who played members of

the support group in the movie, all of whom
have lived with cancer.

And we got to hang with YouTuber Evelina Barry
who was our awesome co-host on the tour.

John: Awww, it's the smile that slayed a thousand
hearts.

Nat: *chuckling*
John: And Nat Wolff

John [voiceover]: Had to get up very early
the next morning to get my hair and makeup

done. It takes a lot of work to wrangle the
puff. And then I had many, many hours of interviews.

John: Hank, press junket interviews are weird
'cuz you talk to a new TV interviewer person

every five minutes for, like, hours.
And it's really hard to talk meaningfully

about, like, anying because 1) you only have
five minutes and 2) they have to get their

quotes and 3) you've been asked the same question
a thousand times before and 4) I was really

worried about saying something stupid and/or
insensitive.

Also, 5) I knew if they made me keep talking
I would eventually get the husky voice and

I have.
Anyways, I realize I am winning like an Olympic

gold medal for the first-worldiest first-world
problems. My point is that it was hard to

engage.
On the upside sometimes we got goodie bags

with treats in them.
Hank the best part about being on tour with

someone who doesn't eat processed food is
that you get Shailene Woodley's GooGoo clusters.

John [voiceover]: Anyway, then we went to
Nashville, a lovely town, where there was

this red carpet like thing and lots of people
to sign for, which is great, but also weird

because I would like to stop and talk to them
and have as near a normal interaction as possible

given the circumstances, but there were these
large men on both sides of me pushing me along

and lots of screaming and just in general
the whole situation was no more conducive

to meaningful conversation than press junkets.
Then I did a few red carpet interviews- again,

difficult to feel connected to the world slash
the actual people in it.

And then we went inside where Nat and Alex
Wolff were playing a concert.

Shailene and I lay down on the floor and peeked
under the curtain to watch.

Also, there were quite a lot of people there
who wanted to say hi to you.
Crowd: Good Morning Hank it's Tuesday.

John [voice over]: Next morning, more hair,
more makeup, and many more hours of press

before going to Dallas where there was another
red carpet and more screaming and bodyguards

and more interviews and then many thousands
of people who, get this, Hank, wanted to wish
you a good morning.
Crowd: Good morning Hank it's Tuesday!

John [voiceover]: I was so grateful to have
this time to see so many nerdfighters and

to talk about the movie with the actors who
helped make it so special, but I also felt

really disconnected. Like, with all these
people from the outside paying attention to

us, I felt really self-conscious as a nerdfighter,
like it was hard for us to be a community

together, which is what I love most about
nerdfighteria. And I was feeling pretty bummed

out about it AND THEN
So Hank during these events people could ask

questions and a young woman named Caroline
came up and introduced herself and talked

about how she's found The Fault in Our Stars
helpful as she lives with lymphoma. She was

pretty emotional as we talked and so was I
and so was the cast and then suddenly thousands

of people in the crowd began chanting her
name.
Crowd: Caroline! Caroline! Caroline! Caroline!

John: I realized Hank that even if we're gonna
be scrutinized for a while by people who don't

know if nerdfighters fight for or against
nerds, nerdfighteria is still nerdfighteria.

I realized the community has never really
been about us, Hank. It's been about having

big conversations around big questions and
lifting up people who need it.

So I want to say thank you nerdfighters from
Miami to Dallas and everywhere in between

for welcoming new people but also sticking
together.

Thank you for lifting each other up and for
decreasing suck and for increasing awesome.

When I am very far from home and feel very
disconnected from my real life, you guys help

me to feel like I am not so far from home
after all. So thank you, I love you.

Not you Hank, everyone else, all the other
people.

Actually, you know what Hank? God help me,
I even love you.

By the way Hank, congrats on your album being
a huge hit on the iTunes charts, it's so great

everyone get it.
Hank, I will see you on Friday when I will

be hoooome!
Ohhhuhh. DFTBA

title: Perfect Puff and Endless Interviews: Touring and Hollywood Press Junkets

comments.text:
I wish the best for Caroline, the kind people who played the support group 
members, and anyone else who lives or had lived with disease. ﻿

comments.text:
Meetups are WEIRD! 100, 300, 1000ths of people wanting their talk and 
little attention, signature, picture with only ONE person. to the point 
where that one person does not have the time for an actual interaction. It 
is the weirdest thing I have ever done. But around that, people get to 
interact with each other. So I made some new friends ^_^. So it is not all 
that bad.  Inside that crowd, people get to meet other people and interact 
because they have this one thing in common.  It is amazing. (but still 
weird)﻿

comments.author: Steven Castilla

comments.text:
Hank is a historic building located in downtown Tucson, Arizona. Hank was 
built in 1919 in conjunction with the musical venue Rialto Theatre, which 
sits across the street. The rear of Hank faces the historic Amtrak station, 
built by Southern Pacific in 1907. In addition to being a hotel, Hank also 
houses a restaurant, bar and music venue.

comments.text:
I love both yours and Hank's videos here on the channel. Since reading your 
book "A Fault in Our Stars" I feel like someone understands what is like to 
be like Hazel, Augustus & Isaac... and how challenging living with a 
terminal disease is and also the complete and utter truth behind the 
unfairness of cancer! I swear I was born to be a nerdfighter, only I didnt 
know about t b e movement when I read AFiOS.... I﻿

comments.author: Julia Creyts

comments.text:
watching since 2010: don't mind a tiny bit of selling out to fund the 
growth of nerd fighteria, but please don't become the tools by which 
monetary interests, corporations and governments control populations. media 
groups are corporations, as are publishers, (as is youtube/google) etc. 
again i totally don't mind it during the growth stage, but create your own 
systems(companies if need be) that don't prioritize profit over content, 
and show the world a better way. the road is paved with good intentions... 
make sure this movement doesn't create curious yet complacent citizenry... 
as well don't wake up one day in old age realizing you've lost your way. 
much respect and love to both you gentle and kind entities!﻿
comments.author: Raymond Lucas (SurelyQuestionable)

comments.text:
I got to see you guys when the tour visited Cleveland, I made my mom drive 
three hours to take me, in hopes that I would get to give a letter I wrote 
to you. I'm a teenage cancer survivor and I want to let you know how much 
the book meant to me in so many ways. I got into the event and another 
cancer survivor who was like RIGHT in front of me got noticed by you :( ! 
The event was neat though, I'm glad you had a somewhat good time. 
﻿
comments.author: Snowtella

comments.text: this warms my heart. i love this community. dftba, nerdfighters <3﻿
comments.author: bookwormgirl000

comments.text:
The cool thing about Nerdfighteria being so big is that there are a ton of 
small communities of Nerdfighters, and almost anybody can find one, at 
least in the US. And on a small scale we do awesome projects and have fun 
and meaningful experiences, and it's cool when the small groups can come 
together too. So yeah, overall it's huge. But it's the intimacy and 
connection between Nerdfighters that matters. ﻿

comments.author: Sam Whitbread

comments.text:
I understand how insane it was during all this press stuff for tfios, as I 
was fortunate enough to attend the event in Miami. At the time I didn't 
feel fortunate though, just disconnected, which now I understand as just to 
be so many passionate people wanting to be connected to you, there had to 
be some missed connections. Looking back it was a great experience and it's 
amazing seeing how much positivity this movie has brought people already, 
along with the book of course. Counting the days until I'm lucky enough to 
see this story from what it's like inside your head, heartache included. No 
hard feelings about Miami but come back would you? We have lots of people 
who love you. Have a fantastic day. ﻿
comments.author: Sarah Glynn

comments.text: I WAS IN THE MIAMI CROWD AT THE BEGINING AHHSHCJCKCJKSMCKD﻿

comments.text:
I was in the Miami event, it was sad as there was A LOT of mass hysteria 
and people couldn't control themselves and especially all the waiting and I 
wish there could've been a signing and if you guys could've stayed longer, 
but I understood why under the circumstances, but still happy I at least 
got to see you guys, love you forever. :-)﻿

words make it more bearable. Thanks :) DFTBA and long live Nerfighteria 3﻿

I'm spending a day in Indianapolis over the summer, crossing my fingers

Never fear, Miamian Nerdfighters! John promised to return to do a signing

comments.author: gus gonzalez

comments.text:
"I realized, Hank, that even if we're going to be scrutinized for a while 
by people who don't know if Nerdfighters fight for or against nerds, 
Nerdfighteria is still Nerdfighteria.  I realized the community has never 
really been about us, Hank.  It's been about having big conversations 
around big questions and lifting up people who need it." - John Green

And I'd like to thank the Brothers Green for creating Nerdfighteria.  Or 
for creating an environment where their followers could create 
Nerdfighteria.  I wish that it had existed when I was a left-of-center 
teen, and I am grateful that it exists for all teens, including mine.﻿

comments.text:
Thank you John, Hank and Nerdfightaria for helping me through so much and i 
was wandering if anyone could help me out. One of my best friends, who like 
me is just 15 years old, is shaving her head for blood cancer. So if you 
could take a minute to read her story or even donate whatever you could ir 
will be endlessly appriciated.
https://www.justgiving.com/Aduma-Massari/
Thank you and Dftba﻿
comments.author: Lucy mallinder

comments.text: My friend Emily was the loudest at the Dallas one!﻿
comments.author: Kris Simpson

comments.text:
Dear John - I just wanted to say that I think people feel disconnected at 
various moments in their life, and it's odd how sometimes it's when you're 
in a crowd of people that you feel most alone and misunderstood.  I hope 
that I speak for all Nerdfighters when I say that we all feel connected to 
you through your videos, and if it's enough for you, then it probably ought 
to be enough for us too! I hope that our community can keep you going 
through the media storm of the next few months, and most importantly please 
remember the words of a brilliant man, that,

 “Whatever you get paid attention for is never what you think is most 
important about yourself.” - David Foster Wallace ﻿
comments.author: Wolfgirl11

comments.text:
Don't worry +John Green  if you feel like you don't have time to say 
anything meaningful in your 5 minute interviews: a 4-minute video seems to 
be quite enough :)﻿

so let me get this straight: there are THAT MANY nerdfighters in Nashville,

comments.author: The Royal Spoon

comments.text:
You may think those signatures aren't much but they are. I found a copies 
of TFIOS, along with, I believe An Abundance of Katherines, Looking for 
Alaska, and Papertowns in my local little home spun book store. They each 
had a little sticker in them with your signature. That may not seem like 
much to you but, after begging my father to purchase me a copy of TFIOS 
with promises to pay him back immediately, I wen home and called a friend 
of mine. She was at a party and when I told her she got so excited she 
began hyperventilating and had to hang u so she wouldn't pass out. I got 
pissed when that book got a few tiny scratches. You don't thing a little 
signature is meaningful but to us it's everything.﻿
comments.author: Holmes Watson (goodmorning221b)

thanks,
beebe ﻿

comments.text:
Hey John, you ever want to have a conversation, I totally up for it! I love 
your books (though I've only read Fault In Our Stars and am currently 
reading Paper Towns) and it would be awesome to just have you go "thanks, 
but no thanks". Though I may say stupid stuff I love your books and the 
humor you use in them and could talk about them for hours (well, okay, 
maybe not that long) but you get my drift. Anyway, bye, I know that's 
probably weird considering you probably won't read this comment since there 
are so many others but you know, thanks for being an author. Oh, and fun 
fact, I also want to be an author. Don't know how well that's gonna go 
though... Okay, I'll shut up now.﻿
